author: Chris Kuc
title: As temperatures warm, Cubs hope bats follow suit - Chicago Tribune
text:
The sun came out a day after the Cubs fell behind 2-0 to the Mets in the National League Championship Series.
While the forecast for the outcome of the best-of-seven series is a bit gloomier than the Cubs would like, at least the weather should be more comfortable for Games 3 and 4 at Wrigley Field on Tuesday and Wednesday nights.
“I’m excited to be back in a little bit warmer weather,” Cubs slugger Kris Bryant said following a light workout Monday at sun-drenched Wrigley Field where the temperature hovered at 70 degrees. “I don’t know what it’s going to be like at night but I’m excited not to wear two long-sleeve shirts.”
Expected daytime highs for Tuesday and Wednesday in Chicago are 72 and 74, respectively, with a chance of spotty rain showers each day. Lows are expected to be 54 and 57. Game-time temperature for Game 2 on Sunday night at Citi Field in New York was 45 degrees.
“It was freezing,” Bryant said “But when you’re playing in the game you don’t really feel it that much. A lot of it is mental. You don’t like playing in the cold but they have to play in the cold too.”
In New York, many of the players wore layers and some featured masks to cover much of their faces while at the plate and in the field. On Monday, both the Cubs and Mets worked out and there were plenty of shorts sleeves and some players wore shorts.
“When I go out to hit I don’t feel the cold, I’m really focused on trying to hit the ball,” Cubs infielder Javier Baez said. “It was really cold and windy but it doesn’t mean we’re going to stop playing the game.”
Joe Maddon on Cubs keeping the faith Cubs manager Joe Maddon on keeping the faith.
Cubs manager Joe Maddon on keeping the faith.
See more videos Still, Baez, who added that “sometimes you don’t feel your hands when it’s really cold,” will welcome warmer temperatures.
“I love the heat,” he said. “I’m pretty sure not many people like the cold. I’m one of those.”
The Cubs mostly rely on their bats to win games and frigid temperatures can be a hindrance. After bashing baseball all season, they have scratched out a combined three runs on 10 hits during the first two games of the series. While much of the struggles can be attributed to superb Mets pitching, a little heat could help.
“Preferably for the lineup, of course the guys will feel their hands a little bit better,” Cubs manager Joe Maddon said. “It should work out somewhat better for us offensively. I would like to believe that, but at the end of the day it's always about the other team and your starting pitching. It's always about starting pitching. I'd like to believe with a little warmer weather, our guys are going to have a little better feel at the plate.”
Cubs Game 3 starter Kyle Hendricks sees benefits to both cold and warm temperatures.
“When it's cold, you can bust guys inside (and) when it's warm, you can warm-up easier,” Hendricks said. “It doesn't matter to me. No matter what the weather is, you've got to make good pitches and keep the ball down. So that's where my focus is.”
